bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 166, Number 19 (Wednesday, January 29, 2020)][House][Pages H712-H713]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mr. RIGGLEMAN:H.R. 5699.[[Page H713]]Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:This bill is enacted pursuant to the power granted toCongress under Article 1, Section 8, Clause 18 of the UnitedStates Constitution.

item.title: Opportunities for Fairness in Farming Act of 2020

latestAction.text: Referred to the House Committee on Agriculture.

item.title: Opportunities for Fairness in Farming Act of 2019

latestAction.text: Read twice and referred to the Committee on Agriculture, Nutrition, and Forestry.
Read twice and referred to the Committee on Agriculture, Nutrition, and Forestry.

item.text: Referred to the House Committee on Agriculture.

summary.text:
Voluntary Checkoff Program Participation Act

This bill prohibits mandatory or compulsory checkoff programs and requires producer participation in the programs to be voluntary at the point of sale. (A checkoff program is a program to promote and provide research and information for a particular agricultural commodity without reference to specific producers or brands. The Department of Agriculture oversees the programs, which are requested and funded by industry.)

bill.title: Voluntary Checkoff Program Participation Act

item.title: To prohibit mandatory or compulsory checkoff programs.

latestAction.text: Referred to the House Committee on Agriculture.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
